Answer: This isn’t a Star Wars problem. It’s a scifi/fantasy problem. Every science fiction storyThis isn’t a Star Wars problem. It’s a scifi/fantasy problem. Every science fiction storyThis is a problem in Star Trek: Literally they’ve solved dozens of problems withSince artificial limits constrain the reality to just bipedal humans with funny rubber on their face, you can get the stories we —the consumers beyond the fourth wall— want to watch. There cannot ever be a logical explanation. In Trek, the computer AI would move a trillion times faster than a human, yet Worf is still pushing the “fire” button on torpedoes. In Star Wars, the presence of magic and some artificial limits on tech make that easier for us to enjoy watching people go on fun adventures.
name: Franklin Veaux

Answer: I have wondered this myself, but then realized my bias was showing. Why must societies forever advance? IRL there have been polities that (by our standards) stagnated but from their perspective traded becoming for being.If you look at LOTRs you can see that the past is more “glorious” and perhaps more advanced that when we meet them in the 3rd age: “much that should have been remembered was forgotten”.The idea of advancement, and that it’s desirable, seems to be something we inherited from the Greeks - but is by no means the only way things can go. You could argue that post-Rome Europe forgotI have wondered this myself, but then realized my bias was showing. Why must societies forever advance? IRL there have been polities that (by our standards) stagnated but from their perspective traded becoming for being.If you look at LOTRs you can see that the past is more “glorious” and perhaps more advanced that when we meet them in the 3rd age: “much that should have been remembered was forgotten”.The idea of advancement, and that it’s desirable, seems to be something we inherited from the Greeks - but is by no means the only way things can go. You could argue that post-Rome Europe forgot many things (not all) and would appear they didn’t ‘progress’.In the case of SW you do see slow advancement over time when the gestalt of galactic society wanted it that way. The period in which we join the story is clearly after the “golden age” by a long stretch…everything looks dingy; under the empire only weapons tech advanced; droid tech was more or less outlawed (or not wanted by those who remembered one version of the clone wars). And so on.

Answer: Don't question Star Wars logic.Star Wars is a prime example of a space opera. This subgenre of science fiction does not concern itself with scientific plausibility.The Star Wars universe follows its own internal logic, but there are no attempts to explain how spaceships can travel through hyperspace, how people can breathe the atmosphere of every planet or how lightsabers work. The “science" of Star Wars need not comply with real-world science.It's sort of a misnomer to label space opera as science fiction at all. There is nothing resembling science in it. In many aspects, it's closer to fantaDon't question Star Wars logic.Star Wars is a prime example of a space opera. This subgenre of science fiction does not concern itself with scientific plausibility.The Star Wars universe follows its own internal logic, but there are no attempts to explain how spaceships can travel through hyperspace, how people can breathe the atmosphere of every planet or how lightsabers work. The “science" of Star Wars need not comply with real-world science.It's sort of a misnomer to label space opera as science fiction at all. There is nothing resembling science in it. In many aspects, it's closer to fantasy.The technology doesn't advance in Star Wars for the simple reason that it allows authors to write stories with all the familiar Star Wars elements (lightsabers, hyperdrive etc.) in a completely different galaxy-political setting.

Answer: Military tactics. Star Wars displays bizarre and ridiculous battle sequences that don't make any sense of you think about them a little.Sure, the Battle of Geonosis looked cool, but it was absolutely silly.It reminds me a bit of WWI, where a bunch of new of innovative technologies were being introduced and people were trying to figure out what made sense both from a technological and military doctrine standpoint. Answer: Because Star Wars is a Samurai cowboy Western in space.The technology in Star Wars exists only to serve Samurai cowboy Westerns in space. Star Wars is not science fiction. It’s about magic swords and space wizards.This is why we see spacecraft flying faster than light equipped with antiaircraft technology that is worse than World War II. This is why we see spaceships dogfighting by swooping and diving, but there’s no BVR missiles and their weapons are so ludicrously ineffective. (Pew Pew Pew!) No combat in Star Wars, technically or tactically, is any more sophisticated than about 1942 or so.

question: https://www.quora.com/The-Star-Wars-Universe-spans-tens-of-thousands-of-years-Why-have-these-beings-had-such-advanced-technology-for-so-long-and-how-come-they-advance-so-slowly

Answer: It’s actually pretty simple.The Star Wars galaxy is absolutely massive, meaning that any technological developments would take hundreds, maybe even thousands of years to expand to the entire galaxy. The lack of major technological breakthroughs is due to Darth Vader, and other Dark Lords of the Sith. If an engineer accidentally fails them, they most likely kill them, no matter how smart the engineer was, what feats they’ve accomplished, just because of one minor screw up. This has slowed down the development of tech in Star Wars incredibly, aside from several breakthroughs in superweapons (I’MIt’s actually pretty simple.The Star Wars galaxy is absolutely massive, meaning that any technological developments would take hundreds, maybe even thousands of years to expand to the entire galaxy. The lack of major technological breakthroughs is due to Darth Vader, and other Dark Lords of the Sith. If an engineer accidentally fails them, they most likely kill them, no matter how smart the engineer was, what feats they’ve accomplished, just because of one minor screw up. This has slowed down the development of tech in Star Wars incredibly, aside from several breakthroughs in superweapons (I’M LOOKING AT YOU, PALPATINE!!!!), the galaxy has remained at relatively the same tech level for thousands of years, also aside from minor, very minor, improvements in weapons, or sublight, or shields, or medical, etc.My point is that with such a big galaxy, it takes time for any new breakthroughs to spread throughout the entire galaxy, especially with as many wars as Star Wars has (hence the name “Star Wars”), this is why we see so little advancements in technology, and quite a few regressions (looks in disappointment at the AT-AT).Thanks for your time.-Wolf

question: https://www.quora.com/The-Star-Wars-Universe-spans-tens-of-thousands-of-years-Why-have-these-beings-had-such-advanced-technology-for-so-long-and-how-come-they-advance-so-slowly

Answer: Isn't it a good idea to send another Voyager space craft now with more advanced technology available today?It would be an excellent missionHistoryThe original Grand Tour was scrapped in the early 70s. Here’s a quote from NASA:TheIsn't it a good idea to send another Voyager space craft now with more advanced technology available today?It would be an excellent missionHistoryThe original Grand Tour was scrapped in the early 70s. Here’s a quote from NASA:TheThen the Voyager mission attempted to take a less grand tour:The Voyager mission was designed to take advantage of a rare geometric arrangement of the outer planets in the late 1970s and the 1980s which allowed for a four-planet tour for a minimum of propellant and trip time. This layout of Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus and Neptune, which occurs about every 175 years, allows a spacecraft on a particular flight path to swing from one planet to the next without the need for large onboard propulsion systems.That too was scrapped:While the four-planet mission was known to be possible, it was deemed to be too expensive to build a spacecraft that could go the distance, carry the instruments needed and last long enough to accomplish such a long mission. Thus, the Voyagers were funded to conduct intensive flyby studies of Jupiter and Saturn only.The Jupiter and Saturn flybys were an immense success but NASA decided to extend the Voyager missions:The mission objective of the Voyager Interstellar Mission (VIM) is to extend the NASA exploration of the solar system beyond the neighborhood of the outer planets to the outer limits of the Sun's sphere of influence, and possibly beyond.That too was a success. Unfortunately the Voyager’s ability to communicate with Earth will cease in the next year or two. They won’t stop flying, they just won’t be able to tell us the glorious sights they see.In about 40,000 years, Voyager 1 will drift within 1.6 light-years of AC+79 3888, a star in the constellation of Camelopardalis which is heading toward the constellation Ophiuchus. In about 40,000 years, Voyager 2 will pass 1.7 light-years from the star Ross 248 and in about 296,000 years, it will pass 4.3 light-years from Sirius, the brightest star in the sky. The Voyagers are destined—perhaps eternally—to wander the Milky Way.I would love to see similar missions, and, as you say, with advanced technology they could be designed to, say, study Uranus and Neptune and then cruise around in the Oort Cloud for many more years than the current Voyagers. They could have similar missions as New Horizons which opened our eyes to Pluto and Charon. That would really be exciting to me.

Answer: Turns out, NASA isn’t super flush with cash.There are literally dozens of space mission concepts proposed to NASA every year. A small fraction get selected for Phase A study, an even smaller for Phase B, and only a subset of those win the competition to actually get launched. [So you better have aAssuming you can show that your idea is technologically feasible, then what you really needTurns out, NASA isn’t super flush with cash.There are literally dozens of space mission concepts proposed to NASA every year. A small fraction get selected for Phase A study, an even smaller for Phase B, and only a subset of those win the competition to actually get launched. [So you better have aAssuming you can show that your idea is technologically feasible, then what you really need is aThis is why nobody has really thought about Voyager 3: already Voyager 1 and 2 have far surpassed expectations. We’ve done a Solar System tour. Been there, done that. I’m sure we could learn some new stuff, but does it really rise to the top compared to all the other things that have never been explored before at all?Wouldn’t you rather look for life in the oceans of Europa? Wouldn’t you rather figure out about water on Mars? Wouldn’t you rather find Earth-like planets around other stars? Wouldn’t you rather see the dawn of the first stars and galaxies in our Universe? Wouldn’t you rather figure out what Dark Energy is?NASA has to balance all these very cool sounding things. Of course it would be awesome to do them all, but that’s just not even close to budgetarily feasible. It would be closer if NASA was funded at the same level as during the Apollo era, but it’s far short of that now.Sadly, I don’t see how Voyager 3 is happening anytime soon.

question: https://www.quora.com/The-Star-Wars-Universe-spans-tens-of-thousands-of-years-Why-have-these-beings-had-such-advanced-technology-for-so-long-and-how-come-they-advance-so-slowly

Answer: Electric cars have been around for over a hundred years. In the early days, there were three main competing technologies- petrol, steam and electric.Petrol cars were fast and had a good range between refuelling, but we're complex to drive and had to be hand-cranked with a strong arm to start. Many inexperienced drivers suffered broken wrists when the handle kicked back. Steam cars were simpler to drive, but required a longer wait to warm up and build pressure before you could go. There was also the need to refill with water as well as fuel. Electric cars were quiet and simple to drive, but theElectric cars have been around for over a hundred years. In the early days, there were three main competing technologies- petrol, steam and electric.Petrol cars were fast and had a good range between refuelling, but we're complex to drive and had to be hand-cranked with a strong arm to start. Many inexperienced drivers suffered broken wrists when the handle kicked back. Steam cars were simpler to drive, but required a longer wait to warm up and build pressure before you could go. There was also the need to refill with water as well as fuel. Electric cars were quiet and simple to drive, but the range was poor. This was also before electricity supplies were particularly widespread or standardised, so recharging may have been problematic.The invention of the electric starter motor and standardised controls basically killed off steam and electric and internal-combustion emerged as the dominant technology for the 20th century. Incremental advances such as automatic transmissions and synchronised manual gearboxes made driving them simpler and further cemented their place at the top. Electricity continued in a few niche applications (such as British milk floats used for early morning deliveries) but for cars, BEVs were basically nonexistent. Terrible examples such as the Sinclair C5 and Reva G-Wiz caused more harm than good to the electric vehicle market.Today, advances in battery technology and electrical infrastructure makes electric vehicles a more practical proposition. Contrary to the political weight currently being placed behind them though, they are not the answer to everyone's needs for every situation. The future will probably be a mixture of battery electric, hydrogen fuel cells and hybrid internal-combustion/electric vehicles running on clean synthetic fuels.

Answer: We can discuss it to our heart’s content, EV’s will compose 90% of the world’s vehicle fleet by 2040.Why?Because EV’s are cheaper to operate. Charging a battery pack is cheaper than buying fuel.Maintaining an electric motor and battery pack is cheaper than maintaining an internal combustion engine.Thus, the adoption curve has started for EV’s.Up until now, batteries cost too much and took too long to charge. Not any more.No person in their right mind will run a vehicle that costs $2800 a year to operate if the equivalent vehicle sitting next to it on the dealership lot cost $800 a year. The paWe can discuss it to our heart’s content, EV’s will compose 90% of the world’s vehicle fleet by 2040.Why?Because EV’s are cheaper to operate. Charging a battery pack is cheaper than buying fuel.Maintaining an electric motor and battery pack is cheaper than maintaining an internal combustion engine.Thus, the adoption curve has started for EV’s.Up until now, batteries cost too much and took too long to charge. Not any more.No person in their right mind will run a vehicle that costs $2800 a year to operate if the equivalent vehicle sitting next to it on the dealership lot cost $800 a year. The party is over and you and I have nothing to do with it.Average range for EV’s will be 350 miles per charge and a “quick” 80 mile charge will be available by 2023.If you think this process will take more than 20 years? Don’t move to Europe. By 2035, sales of ICE’s will be banned while driving them within city limits is already restricted. So, I live outside of London and need to buy a new car in 2023? Just why in hell would I buy an ICE car if it’s going to be against the law to drive it in 12 years?That is one of my favorite modes of locomotion. A GM NorthStar V8. It uses oil, unleaded gasoline, belts, filters, gaskets, exhaust manifolds, pipes and catalytic converters and coolant. It needs oil changes, tune ups, transmission fluid. all of these needs are provided by a guy who needs to be paid on top of the materials cost.There is the future. The electric motor is 1880’s tech and will run constantly for about 20 years. The battery pack is warrantied by federal law for 8 years and its price is dropping at about 10% a year.Good bye NorthStar, I loved your torque and the unequaled V8 rumble, but, you cost too much to run and the federal government has decided that you are a social nuisance.

Answer: As has been said, New Horizons is much the same. But, of course, being launched later, it has not got so far.But the Voyagers were launched to take advantage of a particular configuration of planets which allowed what the called the Grand Tour of several major planets with a single probe. And that was what they were designed to do - to visit Jupiter, Saturn and and Neptune with a single spacecraft and much less time than would normally be needed. The deep space exploration is just a bonus, not part of the original design. But if you can get it, why not?
name: Lucas Curtis
question: https://www.quora.com/The-Star-Wars-Universe-spans-tens-of-thousands-of-years-Why-have-these-beings-had-such-advanced-technology-for-so-long-and-how-come-they-advance-so-slowly

Answer: The New Horizons spacecraft, encountered Jupiter, Pluto, and MU69, exploring all of them. Its instrumentation and return of data are superior to those of the Voyager spacecraft.
name: Lucas Jonne de Jong
question: https://www.quora.com/The-Star-Wars-Universe-spans-tens-of-thousands-of-years-Why-have-these-beings-had-such-advanced-technology-for-so-long-and-how-come-they-advance-so-slowly

Answer: It has a power source that uses the heat generated by decaying, radioactive plutonium. It decays very slowly. It has been generating electricity from the heat the whole time. However, it is cooling down and now only produces a fraction of the electricity that it originally did. NASA has shut down all the unnecessary instruments and uses the electricity to run the radio transmitter.
name: Jake Williams
